If those of you who have read the Mueller Report have additional ideas about how we might codify norms to prevent a repeat of the disgraceful behavior it describes, please share them! (11)

None of this absolves us from the responsibility to investigate the president's actions and reckon with the consequences. But our most basic duty as legislators is to legislate. I hope that members of Congress on both sides, whatever their views on impeachment, will agree. (10)

We should consider how to define more clearly that actions by presidents to influence or shut down investigations in which they have a personal interest -- as Trump repeatedly and blatantly tried to do - are illegal and prosecutable. (9)

Finally, Mueller concluded that "Congress has authority to prohibit a President's corrupt use of his authority in order to protect the integrity of the administration of justice." I read that not just as an invitation to hold Trump accountable, but to legislate. (8)

Third, political candidates should have an affirmative legal duty to report to law enforcement any offer of help coming from a foreign government or that might be illegal, like offers of hacked emails. Just as banks are required to report suspicious transactions. (7)
The rules that prohibit coordination between political candidates and IEs should also apply to coordination with a foreign government or agent of a foreign government. At the very least! (6)

Second, it's illegal for political candidates to share things like polling data and campaign strategy with independent political action groups (IEs) in the US. Yet apparently it's perfectly legal to share that info with Russian spies to help them target our voters. (5)

First, we need to provide funding to secure the machinery of our elections. New Jersey, for example, is struggling to upgrade machines that leave no paper record of votes, and to harden our systems against hacking. We need more federal help. (4)
This means it's up to Congress to act.  Here are some ideas. (3)

The report tells us Trump wasn't working for Russia (thankfully), but also that he wasn't, and isn't, working for America. He's interested only in protecting himself, as DHS Secretary Nielsen found out when she urged action to secure the 2020 election. (2) https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/24/us/politics/russia-2020-election-trump.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage

The 367th Infantry Regiment, known as the "Harlem Hellfighters," suffered more casualties and spent more days in front line trenches than any other American regiment in WWI. In all, more than 367,000 African Americans served in WWI, yet none were awarded the Medal of Honor.

Every single person who played a role in the fight against offshore drilling deserves a round of applause. But this fight is by no means over. We need legislation to permanently protect our coastal communities from the threat of offshore drilling. Congress must pass my bill.

And NOW, Interior Secretary Bernhardt announced that - in part because of the ongoing litigation and clear opposition by elected officials - the Administration was indefinitely postponing their plans to expand offshore oil and gas drilling. This is great news!
Last month, the courts got involved as well. A federal judge ruled that Trump did not have the authority to overturn a ban on offshore drilling in the Arctic and parts of the Atlantic.

We made it clear that opposition to offshore drilling was NOT a partisan issue. We all know that our coastlines are too valuable to our economy, environment, and way of life to jeopardize because when you drill, you spill. And even a small oil spill would devastate our community.

On my 4th day in office, I introduced a bill that would place a ten-year ban on oil and gas leasing. Last month, I introduced a bill that would permanently ban oil and gas drilling on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts - both with bipartisan support.
The reaction from the Lowcountry and coastal communities across the country was immediate. While running for office, I promised I would say hell no to offshore drilling. My opponent... not so much.

I just heard reports that the Trump Adminstration was halting its plans to expand offshore drilling in the Atlantic. How did we get here and what does this mean? In January of 2018, the Interior Dept announced its intention to open up the Atlantic and Pacific to offshore drilling
